thread.title: Telstra's impressive result may be hard act to follow
thread.title_full: Telstra's impressive result may be hard act to follow

title: Telstra's impressive result may be hard act to follow
text:
Return to video Video settings Please Log in to update your video settings

Replay video Return to video Video settings Please Log in to update your video settings
Telstra's new way with Andy Penn As Telstra results come out in line with expectations, AFR reporter James Thomson looks at where the company's new CEO may be pushing the telco to go.
PT1M5S 620 349 Autoplay On Off Video feedback Video settings New Telstra CEO Andrew Penn has delivered a result that should keep investors happy, at least for the time being.
The company deserves several ticks for its performance in the 2015 financial year.
Once you clean up the numbers to adjust for the sale of the Asian mobile business CSL (and other bits and pieces), the underlying result was pretty strong.
The pressure is on Telstra chief executive Andy Penn (right) to continue the strong performance of his predecessor, David Thodey (left). Photo: Cole Bennetts
For the most part investors are looking for a snapshot of how the company grew its all-important mobiles business, how much it managed to curb the fall in its traditional fixed line voice unit and whether the newer growth divisions had progressed towards making a meaningful contribution to the earnings of the very large mother ship.
Lastly, investors are always keen to feel some generosity in dividend payment and are on the lookout for any capital management initiatives.
While the 3.5Â¢ dividend represented an increase over last year, the company failed to deliver any capital management treats and gave no indication that it was considering any more in the near term.
The mobiles business grew retail subscribers by 664,000 which was fairly impressive.
However, it was noteworthy that the rate of growth slowed in the second half - in part because Apple's iPhone 6 was launched in the first half.
But Telstra is clearly disinclined to forecast whether the rate of new subscribers will increase.
The new mobile customers acquisition was clearly a major factor in the overall 10 per cent improvement in revenue over the year, which was also assisted by healthy improvement in average revenue per user and a reduced rate of churn.
The mobile result was pleasing given this is the division that has come in for more intense competition during the year.
Despite that competition, Telstra has been able to hold its margin on sales at 40 per cent.
Whether this margin can be preserved in future, in the face of additional competition and ongoing investment in the network, remains to be seen.
Telstra said several times on Thursday that its focus was on growing revenue in this division and that subscriber numbers would become a less important measure as the trend to connect other devices, like tablets, continued.
Already Australia has one of the world's highest levels of smart phone penetration at about 80 per cent.
So gains in revenue will increasingly rely on customer's spending and increasing their usage.
Telstra's fixed line voice business revenue fell by 7 per cent but this represented the smallest decline in five years. The decline was also partly offset by a similar percentage increase in fixed data revenue.
The up-and-coming Telstra business grew well with the international business (ex CSL) adding around 30 per cent in revenue, a more subdued growth outcome from its media division and the Network Application Services revenue kicking in another 23 per cent - albeit all the divisions are improving off relatively low bases.
Future focus As with all results, the focus will now be on what the Telstra management team can produce in the current and future years.
It is a pivotal time for Telstra. It is parading its new management team around, but the parade brings with it all the attendant uncertainties about how the vast cash flow will be invested or gifted to shareholders.
No one was really expecting any capital management initiatives to be announced on Thursday, so this is unlikely to be a source of investor disappointment.
What investors are keen to get is a sense of how the hundreds of millions of dollars coming from the NBN deal are going to be spent.
In the 2015 year these various NBN contributions topped $800 million and they will only increase over time.
Penn said Telstra's capex to sales ratio would move up from 13.9 per cent in 2015 to 15 per cent in 2016. Sales are forecast to grow from $26.6 billion by mid-single digits in 2016 - so let's assume 5 per cent.
Penn made it clear that Telstra was particularly keen to invest in networks - especially the mobile network - in order to maintain its lead over rivals.
There was lots of discussion around investment in new business and acquisitions - an issue that can tend to spook investors.
Eighteen months ago when the previous chief executive David Thodey mentioned an aspiration that "at least a third of our revenues and profits came from offshore by some period out to 2020 and beyond" the market went into a tailspin and the company ultimately distanced itself from the remarks.
Despite Thursday's solid result Telstra's share price fell by around 2 per cent by lunch.
